snippet: Though the number of deaths of children in car seats has declined, about three out of every four seats are still installed improperly, and it remains a vexing safety issue.
abstract: Car seats, despite being around for decades, remain a vexing safety issue for families unable to figure out how to install them correctly; study finds three-quarters of all seats are improperly installed; automobile crashes are leading cause of death of children 13 and younger, and large number of fatalities involve children in car seats.

byline.original: By STEPHANIE STEINBERG and BILL VLASIC
byline.contributor: Stephanie Steinberg reported from Gaithersburg, Md., and Bill Vlasic from Detroit.

lead_paragraph: Though the number of deaths of children in car seats has declined, about three out of every four seats are still installed improperly, and it remains a vexing safety issue.

headline.seo: Car Seats Remain a Vexing Safety Issue
headline.main: Strapped In, but Still at Risk
headline.print_headline: Strapped In, but Still at Risk
